title: Kenya: Atwoli Pledges National Strike to Back Tutors
text:
By Henry Wanyama 
Cotu yesterday threatened a nationwide strike if the government fails to pay teachers their court-ordered salary increase. 
The union's secretary general Francis Atwoli told striking teachers not to surrender and pledged a paralysing general strike. 
Atwoli addressed a rally at Uhuru Park. 
The event was attended by representatives from teachers' unions, parents associations, public secondary and primary schools heads officials. 
Also present were seven MPs, doctors and nurses unions supported the strike. 
The MPs included John Mbadi (Suba), Oburu Oginga (nominated), Mishi Mboko (Mombasa), Dan Maanzo (Makueni), Opiyo Wandayi (Ugunja) and Raphael Otaalo (Lurambi). 
They warned teachers against surrendering, saying the government will make it a habit not to obey salary awards ordered by the courts. 
"It would be difficult for Asian employers among others to respect Collective Bargaining Agreements ordered by the courts," Atwoli said. 
He said Cotu leaders are ready to join the teachers strike by next week if the government is not willing to honour the 50-60 per cent salary increase. 
Knut secretary general Wilson Sossion said teachers will not go back to class before they get paid. 
He asked Atwoli if workers spoke with one voice in 2002, why not in 2017. Kenya
